case_name: Petitioner v. State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Petition No. 172 of 1956 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 172 of 1956. Under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus. N. Andely, amicus curiae, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner was under detention by virtue of an order dated 5th September 1956 issued by Government of Jammu and Kashmir under section 3(2) and section 12(1) of Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act 2011.

anchor.surface_text: by virtue of an order dated the 5th September, 1956, issued by the Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir under sub-section  2  of sec- tion 3 taken with sub-section  1  of section 12 of Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 2011  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Petitioner first placed under detention by order of District Magistrate Jammu under section 3(2) of the Act on 1st May 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was first placed under detention by virtue of an order passed by the District Magistrate, Jammu, under subsection  2  of section 3 of the Act on the 1st May, 1956,

facts.text: First detention order confirmed and continued on 5th September 1956 by Government under section 12(1) after Advisory Board opinion.

anchor.surface_text: and that order was companyfirmed and companytinued on the 5th September, 1956, under sub-section  1  of section 12 of the Act by the Government after taking the opinion of the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Detention orders recited necessity to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to community.

anchor.surface_text: The two orders of detention, one of the District Magistrate dated the 1st May, 1956, and the other of the Government dated the 5th September, 1956, recited that the petitioner is directed to be detained because it was,

facts.text: Grounds of detention communicated to petitioner on 31st May 1956 by District Magistrate Jammu.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention as companymunicated to the petitioner on the 31st May, 1956, by the District Magistrate, Jammu, are as -follows

facts.text: Petitioner carried on smuggling of essential goods to Pakistan through Ferozpur and Amritsar border, shifted to Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan border.

anchor.surface_text: That you carried on smuggling of essential goods to Pakistan through the Ferozpur and Amritsar border, but since the tightening of said borders you have recently shifted your smuggling activities to Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan borders

facts.text: Petitioner smuggling cloth, zari and mercury to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura border, affecting economic condition of public in Kashmir State.

anchor.surface_text: in the State of Jammu and Kashmir and are carrying on illicit smuggling of essential goods such as cloth, zari and mercury to Pakistan through this border  thus affecting the economic companydition of the public in Kashmir State adversely .

facts.text: Petitioner went to village Darsoopura on 7th April 1956 and contacted Ghulam Ahmed s/o Suraj bin r/o Darsoopura Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura and Ram Lal s/o Frangi r/o Miran Sahib Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura for smuggling.

anchor.surface_text: That for the said purpose of smuggling of goods to Pakistan you went to village Darsoopura on 7th April, 1956, and companytacted Ghulam Ahmed son of Suraj bin resident of Darsoopura Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura and one Ram Lal son of Frangi resident of Miran Sahib Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura

facts.text: Petitioner arranged with aid of Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal for export of Shaffon cloth worth Rs. 2,500 to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura border.

anchor.surface_text: and others who I similarly are addicted to carrying on such a smuggling business and with their aid made arrangements for export of Shaffon cloth worth Rs. 2,500 to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan border.

facts.text: On 11-4-1956, petitioner booked 3 bales of silk cloth through Messrs Jaigopal Rajkumar Shegal of Amritsar to Jammu Tawi addressed to self.

anchor.surface_text: That on 11-4-1956, you booked 3 bales of silk cloth through Messrs Jaigopal Rajkumar Shegal of Amritsar to Jammu Tawi and got these bales on address of yourself,

facts.text: On 11-4-1956, petitioner booked one package of Tila through S. Kanti Lal Zarianwalla of Amritsar addressed to self for Jammu Tawi.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day you got one package of Tila booked through S. Kanti Lal Zarianwalla of Amritsar and got this package also addressed To self for Jammu Tawi.

facts.text: After booking, petitioner came to Jammu, waited for arrival, contacted Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal.

anchor.surface_text: That after booking these packages as aforesaid you came over to Jammu and waited for their arrival and companytacted Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal the above mentioned persons.

facts.text: On 15th April 1956, petitioner tried to get transport receipt from Punjab National Bank but failed as public holiday; goods seized by Central Customs and Excise Department of India.

anchor.surface_text: That on the 15th April, 1956, you tried to get the transport receipt from the Punjab National. Bank but did number succeed in doing so as it was a public holiday. Meanwhile your activities leaked out and the goods were seized by the Central Customs and Excise Department of India.

facts.text: High Court of Jammu and Kashmir delivered judgment dated 21st June 1956 on batch of applications including petitioner's.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Jammu and Kashmir, to whom a similar application was filed by this petitioner along with a number of others similarly detained for illicit smuggling of goods, has in its judgment dated the 21st June, 1956

facts.text: High Court held Shaffon cloth not within category of essential commodity under Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Ordinance of Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: held that Shaffon cloth is number within the category of an essential companymodity as defined in the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Ordinance of Jammu and Kashmir.

facts.text: Zari not an essential commodity under the Ordinance, as stated by counsel for State on instructions.

anchor.surface_text: But in answer to a query from this Court, Shri Porus Mehta who appeared before us on behalf of the State of Jammu and Kashmir has stated, on instructions, that zari which is obviously a luxury article is number one of the companymodities declared essential

facts.text: High Court held mercury is an essential commodity as non-ferrous metal under the Ordinance and upheld petitioner's detention.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Dwarika Das Bhatia stands on s different footing altogether. The allegation against him is that he smuggled into Pakistan some goods such as cloth and zari along with a certain quantity of mercury. Mercury is a number-ferrous metal and according to the definition of an essential companymodity given in the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Ordinance, mercury is an essential companymodity. This being so, Dwarika Das Bhatias detention cannot be challenged.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds detention order illegal because two out of three goods (Shaffon cloth and zari) not essential, relying on precedents.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

facts.text: No material shows smuggling was substantially only mercury; particulars relate to cloth and zari.

anchor.surface_text: No material is placed before us enabling us to say that the smuggling attributed to the petitioner was substantially only of mercury and that the smuggling as regards the other two companymodities was of an inconsequential nature. On the other hand the fact that the particulars furnished to the detenue on the 31st May, 1956, relate only to cloth and zari

facts.text: Petitioner's name is Dwarika Das Bhatia.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Dwarika Das Bhatia stands on s different footing altogether.

facts.text: High Court set aside detention of number of others as smuggling not of essential goods.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, when it dealt with the batch of applications, of which the application of the petitioner before us was one, set aside the detention of number of others on the ground that the smuggling attributed to the individuals companycerned in those cases was number of essential goods.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J. on 1 November 1956.

concepts.unlisted_description: From Shibban Lal Saksena, Keshav Talpade; applies when grounds inseparable.

anchor.surface_text: The power to issue a detention order under section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act depends entirely upon the satisfaction of the appropriate authority specified in that section.

concepts.interpretation: Satisfaction must be based on all stated grounds; invalid grounds prevent judicial assessment of whether order would stand alone.

issues.text: whether since the detention is based on the assumption that Shaffon cloth and zari as well as mercury are all essential goods and since two out of the three categories of the goods with reference to the smuggling of which the detention has been directed, are found not to be essential goods, the entire order is illegal, although one of the items, viz., mercury is an essential commodity

holdings.text: the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detention based on smuggling three commodities where two (cloth, zari) not essential and particulars indicate their smuggling not inconsequential, so invalid grounds vitiate order as per subjective satisfaction principle from precedents

holdings.text: if some out of them are found to be non-existent or irrelevant, the very exercise of that power is bad [...] the Court cannot predicate what the subjective satisfaction of the said authority would have been on the exclusion of those grounds or reasons

anchor.surface_text: The principle underlying all these decisions is this power is vested in a statutory authority to deprive the liberty of a subject on its subjective satisfaction with reference to- specified matters, if that satisfaction is stated to be based on a Dumber of grounds or for a variety of reasons all taken together, and if some out of them are found to be number- existent or irrelevant, the very exercise of that power is bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj, Shibban Lal Saksena, Keshav Talpade: detention power's subjective satisfaction must rest on all grounds; invalid ones prevent judicial assessment of what satisfaction would be without them

holdings.text: In applying these principles, however, the Court must be satisfied that the vague or irrelevant grounds are such as, if excluded, might reasonably have affected the subjective satisfaction of the appropriate authority

anchor.surface_text: In applying these principles, however, the Court must be satisfied that the vague or irrelevant grounds are such as-, if excluded, might reasonably have affected the subjective satisfaction of the appropriate authority. It is number merely because some ground or reason of a companyparatively unessential nature is defective that such an order based on subjective satisfaction can be held to be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifying principle from precedents: vitiation applies only where invalid grounds reasonably material to authority's satisfaction, not trivial defects

holdings.text: this constitutional requirement must be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds communicated to the person detained [...] detention cannot be held to be in accordance with the procedure established by law within the meaning of article 21

anchor.surface_text: We are Of opinion that this constitutional requirement must be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds companymunicated to the person detained, subject of companyrse to a claim of the privilege under clause 6 of article 22. That number having been done in regard to the ground mentioned the petitioners detention cannot be held to be in accordance with the procedure established by law within the meaning of article 21.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approving Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj: each ground must enable representation under Art.22; vagueness infringes Art.21 procedure (analogous to irrelevance here)

holdings.text: the vagueness of one or some of the various grounds vitiates the entire order

anchor.surface_text: and 2 whether the vagueness of one or some of the various grounds vitiates the entire order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: From Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj, applied analogously to irrelevant grounds in this case

precedents.citation: Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v. The,, State of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v. The,, State of Delhi 1

precedents.case_name: Dr Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: vagueness of one or some of the various grounds vitiates the entire order of detention; constitutional requirement must be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds communicated
precedents.cited_holding: Preventive detention is a serious invasion of personal liberty and such meager safeguards as the Constitution has provided against the improper exercise of the power must be jealously watched and enforced by the Court [...] That not having been done in regard to the ground mentioned the petitioners detention cannot be held to be in accordance with the procedure established by law within the meaning of article 21.

precedents.citation: Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of P.  2

anchor.surface_text: Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of P.  2

precedents.case_name: Shibban Lal Saksena v State of U P
precedents.cited_proposition: if one of the grounds of detention is irrelevant or unsubstantiated, the detention order is vitiated as a whole since the court cannot assess the extent to which each ground contributed to the subjective satisfaction
precedents.cited_holding: The detaining authority gave here two grounds for detaining the petitioner. [...] To say that the other ground, which still remains, is quite sufficient to sustain the order, would be to substitute an objective judicial test for the subjective decision of the executive authority [...] this would vitiate the detention order as a whole.

anchor.surface_text: Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidyas case 3

precedents.cited_proposition: obligation cast on the detaining authority to supply grounds is for the purpose of enabling a detenue to make a fair representation to the authority concerned and to the Advisory Board

precedents.citation: Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 1

precedents.cited_proposition: if some of multiple reasons for detention are held bad, it cannot be certain to what extent the bad reasons operated on the mind of the authority or if the order would have been made without them
precedents.cited_holding: If a detaining authority gives four reasons for detaining a man, without distinguishing between them, and any two or three of the reasons are held to be bad, it can never be certain to what extent the bad reasons operated on the mind of the authority or whether the detention order would have been made at all if only one or two good reasons had been before them.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

outcome.relief_summary: The order of detention is bad and must be quashed

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.
We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

The principle underlying all these decisions is this power is vested in a statutory authority to deprive the liberty of a subject on its subjective satisfaction with reference to- specified matters, if that satisfaction is stated to be based on a Dumber of grounds or for a variety of reasons all taken together, and if some out of them are found to be number- existent or irrelevant, the very exercise of that power is bad.
We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

In applying these principles, however, the Court must be satisfied that the vague or irrelevant grounds are such as-, if excluded, might reasonably have affected the subjective satisfaction of the appropriate authority. It is number merely because some ground or reason of a companyparatively unessential nature is defective that such an order based on subjective satisfaction can be held to be invalid.
We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.
der, would be to substitute an objective judicial test for the subjective decision of the executive authority which is against the legislative policy
